Here in the US the penetration of Biosimilars is much lower than in other places‚Ä¶ we need to break this rebate trap that creates significant disincentives for providers and insurance companies.
"All these proposals eliminating the rebate rule are transformational and will disrupt the way we do business. I would like to have a transparent single system." ~ Albert Bourla, CEO
The reason we exist is to create breakthroughs that will change patients' lives.
We will not keep a single dollar if a rebate rule passes.

Pfizer is all about breakthroughs that change patients‚Äô lives. It‚Äôs why our more than 90,000 colleagues come to work every day. And it‚Äôs why we are here today, to ensure we can continue to discover medicines that can change patients‚Äô lives.
Adverse incentives that favor higher-cost biologics are keeping lower-cost biosimilars from reaching patients. We can‚Äôt think of a more concerning example of a broken system.
An important first step is capping the out-of-pocket costs seniors experience in the Medicare drug program.
Imagine a system where Pfizer gets paid based on the number of heart attacks prevented, rather than the number of pills we sold.

Pfizer supports a system in which transparent, upfront discounts directly benefit patients. In the current system, none of the approximately 12 billion dollars in rebates that Pfizer paid in 2018 found its way to American patients.
New breakthroughs are coming quickly to treat many difficult and devastating diseases. But these breakthroughs won‚Äôt do anyone any good if patients can‚Äôt afford them.
Today our CEO Albert Bourla is taking part in an important policy discussion within the United States Senate.
